For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles.     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to connect \u201chybridized mode\u201d and \u201cchiral light\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network target\n  a) Chiral entanglement swapping: use a direction\u2010dependent beam splitter (\u201cchiral coupler\u201d) that hybridizes two spatial modes (hybridized mode) to perform an entanglement\u2010swapping measurement. The output is a non\u2010maximally entangled two\u2010photon state whose Schmidt weights are tunable via the coupler\u2019s directional reflectivities.\n  b) Chiral multiparty router: pre\u2010share Bell pairs between Alice\u2013Bob and Alice\u2013Charlie, then mix one photon from each pair in a three\u2010port \u201chybrid\u201d interferometer with built\u2010in directionality (chiral tritter). A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. The result is a coherent superposition of which swap succeeded\u2014i.e. entangling four distant parties in a \u201cwhich\u2010path\u201d superposition.\nStep 2: Check novelty and pytheus\u2010feasibility\n  a) Novel: no one has used directional (nonreciprocal) couplers for entanglement swapping to tune the output entanglement. Feasible: uses only linear optics, ancillas, heralding. Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter transmissivities and source connections.\n  b) Interesting but more complex\u2014three\u2010port interferometer may push pytheus\u2019s mode count high.\n  c) Quite exotic\u2014superposition of two swap stations requires interference of ancillas across setups\u2014harder to converge.\nStep 3: Pick (a) as most promising.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because: \n  \u2013 No existing quantum\u2010optics candidate has exploited chiral (direction\u2010dependent) coupling to steer entanglement\u2010swapping weights. It blends nonreciprocal routing and hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing into a single measurement device, giving direct control over the entanglement spectrum.\nStep 5: This is feasible in pytheus because: \n  \u2013 It only uses two standard SPDC pair sources (probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources), a single directional/hybrid beam splitter (modeled by tunable transmissivities), two heralding detectors, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feedforward or cavities, fully within pytheus\u2019s optimization of linear\u2010optical networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement-Swapping Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources producing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D). Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. By sweeping each R\u1d62 from \u00bd (weak, unsharp) to 1 (ultrastrong, near-projective) coupling, we realize a genuine measurement-induced quantum network primitive and systematically explore how KCBS inequality violations survive under partial-strength sequential measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static LOQC Realization of the Entanglement-Assisted (2,3) Quantum Secret Sharing Supermap\n\nAbstract: We experimentally implement the EA(2,3) threshold secret-sharing supermap (target: EA_23_secret_share) as an entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting code using only passive linear optics, one single-photon emitter, and two pre-shared Bell-pair sources. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Agnostic Teleportation via a Single Four-Photon Joint Measurement\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe realize the PyTheus-compatible target of phase-invariant quantum teleportation across an unknown-detuned repeater by employing one symmetric four-photon joint detection that exactly cancels the cavity detuning \u03c6 on node B. In this purely passive linear-optical protocol, an arbitrary qubit encoded in node A\u2019s photonic Bell pair is heraldedly transferred onto node C\u2019s matter qubit using only fixed beam splitters, phase shifters, vacuum ancillas, and number-resolving detectors, with no active tuning or feedback required.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Remote CNOT via Gate Teleportation with Maximized Entangling Power\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target \u201cheralded remote CNOT via gate teleportation with maximal entangling power,\u201d realizing a genuine nonlocal two-qubit CNOT purely by linear optics, SPDC Bell pairs, single-photon emitters, and post-selection on trivial Pauli corrections. By embedding entangling-power as the central resource metric and optimizing beam-splitter reflectivities and phase-shifts under realistic SPD\u2009+\u2009PNR detector models, the protocol probabilistically heralds a deterministic remote CNOT with maximal worst-case concurrence.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Testing Non-Commutativity of Dissipative Lindblad Channels via Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static, purely linear-optical network using two SPDC Bell-pair sources, amplitude- and phase-damping beam-splitter ancillas, and a post-selected Bell-state measurement to swap entanglement through the two Lindblad maps L\u2081 (amplitude damping) and L\u2082 (phase damping) in both orders. By heralding the \u03a6\u207a outcome and comparing A\u2013D output fidelities under L\u2081\u2218L\u2082 versus L\u2082\u2218L\u2081, we directly quantify the target non-zero commutator [L\u2081,L\u2082], thus probing the non-commutativity of Markovian dissipative channels.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement-Swapping Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources producing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D). Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While using a nonreciprocal \u201cchiral coupler\u201d to dial the entanglement degree in an entanglement\u2010swapping node is an appealing twist, it is essentially equivalent to the previously proposed PT-symmetric (non-Hermitian) Bell-state analyser or directional entanglement-swapping schemes. Both of those use asymmetric, gain-loss or skin-effect beam splitters to herald a two-photon state |00\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03c6}|11\u27e9 with tunable non-maximal entanglement. This new proposal does not introduce a fundamentally different network primitive or leverage a genuinely new quantum resource. It remains a straightforward variant of known tunable, non-unitary swapping protocols and thus lacks the novelty threshold for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This target is too close to the PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping scheme (non-Hermitian Bell analyzer with tunable \u03b3) and to earlier directional skin-effect swapping proposals. To be novel, you need a qualitatively new element\u2014e.g. a coupling that intermixes more than two paths in a truly non-reciprocal topological way, or a multi-party chiral-order of swaps that leads to an entanglement pattern unseen in the literature\u2014rather than just a tunable asymmetric 2\u00d72 coupler."
}

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"hybridized mode\" and \"chiral light\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The output is a non\u2010maximally entangled two\u2010photon state whose Schmidt weights are tunable via the coupler\u2019s directional reflectivities.\n  b) Chiral multiparty router: pre\u2010share Bell pairs between Alice\u2013Bob and Alice\u2013Charlie, then mix one photon from each pair in a three\u2010port \u201chybrid\u201d interferometer with built\u2010in directionality (chiral tritter). A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. The result is a coherent superposition of which swap succeeded\u2014i.e. entangling four distant parties in a \u201cwhich\u2010path\u201d superposition.\nStep 2: Check novelty and pytheus\u2010feasibility\n  a) Novel: no one has used directional (nonreciprocal) couplers for entanglement swapping to tune the output entanglement. Feasible: uses only linear optics, ancillas, heralding. Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter transmissivities and source connections.\n  b) Interesting but more complex\u2014three\u2010port interferometer may push pytheus\u2019s mode count high.\n  c) Quite exotic\u2014superposition of two swap stations requires interference of ancillas across setups\u2014harder to converge.\nStep 3: Pick (a) as most promising.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because: \n  \u2013 No existing quantum\u2010optics candidate has exploited chiral (direction\u2010dependent) coupling to steer entanglement\u2010swapping weights. It blends nonreciprocal routing and hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing into a single measurement device, giving direct control over the entanglement spectrum.\nStep 5: This is feasible in pytheus because: \n  \u2013 It only uses two standard SPDC pair sources (probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources), a single directional/hybrid beam splitter (modeled by tunable transmissivities), two heralding detectors, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feedforward or cavities, fully within pytheus\u2019s optimization of linear\u2010optical networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement-Swapping Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources producing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D). Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This target is too close to the PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping scheme (non-Hermitian Bell analyzer with tunable \u03b3) and to earlier directional skin-effect swapping proposals.     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: I brainstormed three ways to marry \u201chybridized mode\u201d and \u201cchiral light\u201d in a purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla-heralded quantum network:\n  a) A 2\u00d72 directional (chiral) beam splitter performing entanglement swapping with tunable Schmidt weights.\n  b) A 3-port chiral \u201ctritter\u201d that routes entanglement between different party pairs on demand.\n  c) A 4-mode chiral hybrid coupler that conditionally implements two distinct Bell measurements\u2014one \u201cdirect\u201d swap (A\u2013D) and one \u201ccrossed\u201d swap (A\u2013C & B\u2013D)\u2014thus functioning as a reconfigurable entanglement router.\nStep 2:  \n  a) too close to known PT-symmetric schemes.  \n  b) promising but may exceed Pytheus\u2019s typical node count.  \n  c) novel: no prior demonstration of a single chiral coupler enabling two orthogonal swap channels, and fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics + heralding capabilities.\nStep 3: Pick (c).\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it uses a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d to realize two orthogonal Bell-measurement channels in one device\u2014one channel swaps A\u2194D, the other \u201ccross-swaps\u201d A\u2194C & B\u2194D\u2014thereby implementing a heralded entanglement router. I haven\u2019t seen any linear-optical network that conditionally reconfigures the entanglement graph simply by which pair of detectors clicks.\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only requires two probabilistic SPDC sources, four heralding detectors, and a 4-mode interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) with no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent photon\u00ad-pair sources generating Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. By sweeping each R\u1d62 from \u00bd (weak, unsharp) to 1 (ultrastrong, near-projective) coupling, we realize a genuine measurement-induced quantum network primitive and systematically explore how KCBS inequality violations survive under partial-strength sequential measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static LOQC Realization of the Entanglement-Assisted (2,3) Quantum Secret Sharing Supermap\n\nAbstract: We experimentally implement the EA(2,3) threshold secret-sharing supermap (target: EA_23_secret_share) as an entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting code using only passive linear optics, one single-photon emitter, and two pre-shared Bell-pair sources.  By mixing the dealer\u2019s unknown qubit with the Bell halves into three optical share modes via beam splitters and phase shifters, any two players can cooperatively route their modes through a static LOQC decoder and heraldedly reconstruct the dealer\u2019s secret, while individual players gain no information.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. A single two-port interference measurement on this state directly yields fringes at the total phase \u03c6\u2081+\u03c6\u2082+\u03c6\u2083, realizing Heisenberg-limit scaling for three-node sum-phase estimation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Realization of the Measurement-Only Braiding Superchannel for Two Logical Majorana Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose an experiment targeting the implementation of the measurement-only braiding superchannel \ud835\udd05 on two logical Majorana qubits encoded in four dual-rail photonic modes. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While using a nonreciprocal \u201cchiral coupler\u201d to dial the entanglement degree in an entanglement\u2010swapping node is an appealing twist, it is essentially equivalent to the previously proposed PT-symmetric (non-Hermitian) Bell-state analyser or directional entanglement-swapping schemes. Both of those use asymmetric, gain-loss or skin-effect beam splitters to herald a two-photon state |00\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03c6}|11\u27e9 with tunable non-maximal entanglement. This new proposal does not introduce a fundamentally different network primitive or leverage a genuinely new quantum resource. It remains a straightforward variant of known tunable, non-unitary swapping protocols and thus lacks the novelty threshold for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This target is too close to the PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping scheme (non-Hermitian Bell analyzer with tunable \u03b3) and to earlier directional skin-effect swapping proposals. To be novel, you need a qualitatively new element\u2014e.g. a coupling that intermixes more than two paths in a truly non-reciprocal topological way, or a multi-party chiral-order of swaps that leads to an entanglement pattern unseen in the literature\u2014rather than just a tunable asymmetric 2\u00d72 coupler.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent photon\u00ad-pair sources generating Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed chiral entanglement\u2010router is essentially another variant of the static entanglement-routing primitives already covered in the ensemble (for instance the \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d) and the directional swapping schemes (PT-symmetric or skin-effect couplers) for on-demand routing. Swapping along one diagonal versus the other conditioned on different herald clicks is exactly the same high-level network task of \u201cselectable\u201d Bell projections, only dressed here with a nonreciprocal coupler rather than a multiport mesh. It adds only an implementation tweak, not a genuinely new quantum-network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals. To clear the PRL novelty bar, you\u2019d need a fundamentally new routing primitive (e.g. multi-party chiral topology with non-trivial causal orders or higher-order network invariants) rather than just switching between two swap outcomes with an asymmetric 2\u00d72 coupler."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"hybridized mode\" and \"chiral light\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. The output is a non\u2010maximally entangled two\u2010photon state whose Schmidt weights are tunable via the coupler\u2019s directional reflectivities.\n  b) Chiral multiparty router: pre\u2010share Bell pairs between Alice\u2013Bob and Alice\u2013Charlie, then mix one photon from each pair in a three\u2010port \u201chybrid\u201d interferometer with built\u2010in directionality (chiral tritter). A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. The result is a coherent superposition of which swap succeeded\u2014i.e. entangling four distant parties in a \u201cwhich\u2010path\u201d superposition.\nStep 2: Check novelty and pytheus\u2010feasibility\n  a) Novel: no one has used directional (nonreciprocal) couplers for entanglement swapping to tune the output entanglement. Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter transmissivities and source connections.\n  b) Interesting but more complex\u2014three\u2010port interferometer may push pytheus\u2019s mode count high.\n  c) Quite exotic\u2014superposition of two swap stations requires interference of ancillas across setups\u2014harder to converge.\nStep 3: Pick (a) as most promising.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because: \n  \u2013 No existing quantum\u2010optics candidate has exploited chiral (direction\u2010dependent) coupling to steer entanglement\u2010swapping weights. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - I haven\u2019t seen any linear-optical network that conditionally reconfigures the entanglement graph simply by which pair of detectors clicks.\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only requires two probabilistic SPDC sources, four heralding detectors, and a 4-mode interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) with no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent photon\u00ad-pair sources generating Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals.     "output": "Here is a novel *multi\u2010hop, nonreciprocal entanglement\u2010swapping* network that fuses \u201chybridized modes\u201d and \u201cchiral light,\u201d yet stays well within Pytheus\u2019s domain (linear optics + SPDC pair sources + heralding).  \n\nExplanation  \n---------  \n1. We start with three probabilistic SPDC sources producing Bell pairs on modes  \n   \u2013 Source 1: A \u2194 B\u2081  \n   \u2013 Source 2: B\u2082 \u2194 C\u2081  \n   \u2013 Source 3: C\u2082 \u2194 D  \n2. In the usual two\u2010step swap one would do a Bell measurement on (B\u2081,B\u2082) at node B and another on (C\u2081,C\u2082) at node C. Here we *fuse* both Bell\u2010analyzers into a single **4-mode chiral hybrid coupler** (a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal / direction-dependent).  \n3. The four internal modes B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 are fed into that chiral coupler. Its four outputs go to heralding detectors H0\u2013H3.  \n4. A suitable two\u2010click pattern (for instance H0+H2) projects onto the *sequential* swapping outcome: A and D become entangled. Crucially, because the coupler is chiral, the \u201cwhich\u2010swap\u2010happens\u2010first\u201d amplitudes from the B-measurement versus the C-measurement *interfere* in a direction\u2010dependent way, yielding a *nonreciprocal two\u2010hop swap.*  \n5. By tuning the internal beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases of the chiral coupler (optimized by Pytheus), one can explore the full family of A\u2013D entangled states and directly map out how nonreciprocity affects multi-hop entanglement transport.  \n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):  \n\n   SPDC1:  [  A  ]\u2015\u2022  \n                    \\  \n   SPDC2:  [ B\u2082 ]\u2015\\  >\u2014[ chiral 4-mode interferometer ]\u2014H0  \n             [ B\u2081 ]\u2015/                                  \u2014H1  \n   SPDC3:  [ C\u2081 ]\u2015\\                                  \u2014H2  \n             [ C\u2082 ]\u2015/                                  \u2014H3  \n                    /  \n   SPDC3:  [  D  ]\u2015\u2022  \n\n\u2013 The two solid \u2022 at A and D are the surviving photons that end up entangled after herald clicks.  \n\u2013 H0\u2013H3 are four herald detectors; a two\u2010click pattern (e.g. H0+H2) implements the two Bell measurements in one shot.  \n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target  \n----------------------------------  \n\u2022 Quantum\u2010network focus: a *two-hop entanglement swap* fused into a *single chiral hybrid coupler,* rather than two independent Bell analyzers.  \n\u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (4-mode interferometer mixing B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 into new hybrid outputs) with \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal beam-splitter ratios \u2192 direction-dependent interference between the two swap stages).  \n\u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical + SPDC + heralding; no feedback, no cavities, no resonances.  \n\u2022 Easily generalized to N hops by building larger\u2010mode chiral couplers; allows systematic study of nonreciprocal entanglement transport.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton  \n-----------------------  \n{  \n  \"description\":      \"Two\u2010hop nonreciprocal entanglement swap via a 4-mode chiral coupler\",  \n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_multi_hop_swap\",  \n  \"edges_tried\":      40,  \n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\":          4,            # B\u2081,B\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082  \n  \"num_pre\":          1,  \n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"samples\":          20,  \n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # entangled qubit on modes A,D  \n  \"in_nodes\":         [],  \n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],         # designate detectors 0\u2192A, 3\u2192D as outputs  \n  \"anc_detectors\":    [1,2,4,5],     # H0\u2013H3 on the chiral coupler  \n  \"heralding_out\":    [[1,3]],       # e.g. H0+H2 herald A\u2013D entanglement  \n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}  \n\nExpert\u2019s next steps  \n-------------------  \n\u2022 Ask Pytheus to optimize the internal 4\u00d74 interferometer (beam\u2010splitter angles + phases) so that the chosen two\u2010click herald truly implements the product of the two sequential Bell\u2010projections.  \n\u2022 Sweep different herald patterns or coupler asymmetries to map out nonreciprocal behavior.  \n\u2022 Extend to longer chains (5-mode, 6-mode chiral couplers) for N-hop studies.  \n\nThis experiment sits squarely in the domain of *complex quantum networks* (multi-hop swapping) and brings in both *hybridized spatial modes* and *chiral, direction-dependent interference*\u2014a combination we haven\u2019t yet seen in Pytheus\u2019s library."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Multiparty Entanglement Routing in Quantum Networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Time-Warping Invariant Quantum Recurrent Neural Networks via\n  Quantum-Classical Adaptive Gating\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Optimal entanglement distribution policies in homogeneous repeater\n  chains with cutoffs\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas.
