I haven\u2019t seen any linear-optical network that conditionally reconfigures the entanglement graph simply by which pair of detectors clicks.\nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only requires two probabilistic SPDC sources, four heralding detectors, and a 4-mode interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus) with no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent photon\u00ad-pair sources generating Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals. Uses only SPDC pairs, vacuum ancilla, a passive 3\u00d73 interferometer, and photon-counting heralds. No cavities or feedback.\n Step 3: Choose (c).\n Step 4: This idea is novel because it generalizes entanglement swapping from \u201ctwo-way\u201d routing to \u201cthree-way\u201d routing, embedding all three Bell-projective measurements (on the two incoming photons in modes B,C plus a vacuum port) into a single chiral 3\u00d73 coupler. A two-click herald among the three outputs deterministically picks which pair of end nodes becomes entangled\u2014never before proposed in linear optics.\n Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n   \u2022 Inputs: two probabilistic SPDC sources (modes A\u2013B and C\u2013D) + one vacuum input.\n   \u2022 Linear optics only: a single 3\u00d73 interferometer (to be optimized).\n   \u2022 Heralding: three photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on the three output ports (choose any two-click pattern).\n   \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities, fully within Pytheus\u2019s optimization capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201c3-Way Chiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  We start with two independent SPDC sources creating Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D).  A third input is vacuum (mode V).  We send modes B,C,V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical network with no symmetry constraint).  Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair.  By proper design of the 3\u00d73 unitary, these three detection patterns yield three orthogonal Bell-measurements, routing the entanglement along one of three distinct edges in the four-node network.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510        out node ]  \n             B\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524\u2500\u2510      \u250c\u2500 H0  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u2514\u2500[3\u00d73 coupler]\u2500 H1  \n             D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524               \u2514\u2500 H2  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n  After heralding on any two clicks among H0\u2013H2, the corresponding two remote modes are left in |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2022 Network transformation: a single multi\u2010outcome entanglement-swapping device.  \n  \u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u00d73 mixing of two photon modes + vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (no reciprocity assumption\u2014Pytheus can optimize arbitrary non-symmetric scattering matrix).  \n  \u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Opens a whole family of multi-way entanglement routers by changing the interferometer size and number of heralding ports.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: herald to entangle AD, AC or BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Bell correlations\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],            # Inputs: SPDC sources and vacuum connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],     # modes A(0),D(3),C(1),B(2) for various herald patterns\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],       # A third input is vacuum (mode V).  \n  \u2022 Coupler: B,C,V are injected into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear-optical interferometer with no reciprocity constraint.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs are monitored by photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0, H1, H2. We post-select on exactly two clicks. There are three possible two\u2010click patterns, each implementing a different Bell projection on which two of {B,C,V} were measured:  \n     1) {H0,H1} heralds a Bell\u2010measurement on B&C \u2192 entangles A\u2013D  \n     2) {H0,H2} heralds B&V \u2192 entangles A\u2013C  \n     3) {H1,H2} heralds C&V \u2192 entangles B\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Outputs: the un-measured two modes are left in a Bell state. By which pair clicks, the router \u201cchooses\u201d which link in the four-node network carries the entanglement, all in one static device.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum-network primitive: a multi-outcome entanglement-swapping router.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing B,C,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding; no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable to N-way routers by expanding to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: conditional Bell swaps AD/AC/BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],      # Bell correlations\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # SPDC sources inject directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],        # A(0), D(3), C(1), B(2) depending on herald\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],          # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,6]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n\u2013 Run Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler\u2019s internal beam splitters and phases so that each two\u2010click pattern implements one of the three orthogonal Bell projections.  \n\u2013 Verify that the resulting heralds indeed route entanglement along the intended edge.  \n\u2013 Extend to N-way routing by increasing the interferometer dimension and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal is too close to existing multi-way entanglement routers. We post\u2010select on exactly two\u2010click events.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: three distinct detector pairs correspond uniquely to three Bell states of the original A\u2013B pair; any other pattern is \u201cfail.\u201d  \n  \u2022 Result: the analyzer unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states with success probability >\u00bd, thanks to the directionality of the coupler breaking the usual linear\u2010optics symmetry.\n\nVisualization (modes \u2192 coupler \u2192 detectors):\n  A1\u2500\u2510  \n       \u251c\u2500\u25ba  \n  B1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba 4\u00d74 chiral coupler \u2500\u25ba H0  \n  C1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba                 \u2500\u25ba H1  \n  V \u2500\u2518                  \u2500\u25ba H2  \n                         \u2500\u25ba H3  \n  A2,B2,C2 are idle outputs or dumped.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network functionality: a Bell\u2010measurement building block for teleportation/entanglement\u2010swapping networks.  \n  \u2013 Combines hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing and chiral (nonreciprocal) interferometry.  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of chiral analyzers by varying ancilla count and coupler size.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome Bell discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_bell_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\", \n  \"num_anc\":          2,            #     "output": "Here\u2019s a genuinely new network primitive that sits squarely in Pytheus\u2019s sweet spot\u2014no cavities, no feedback, pure linear-optical + heralding\u2014but achieves a **\u201cchiral teleportation switch\u201d**, i.e. teleport an unknown qubit at A **either** to receiver B\u2032 **or** to receiver C\u2032, **on demand** (by which herald clicks), all in one static device that fuses \u201chybridized mode\u201d mixing with \u201cchiral light\u201d non-reciprocity.\n\n\u2014  \nEXPLANATION  \n1) Resources  \n \u2022 Input mode A carries an unknown qubit (from a single-photon emitter).  \n \u2022 Two SPDC (probabilistic Bell-pair) sources produce entangled photons on (B,B\u2032) and (C,C\u2032).  \n\n2) Hybridized\u2013chiral Bell measurement  \n \u2022 Modes A, B, C are injected into a single 3\u00d73 linear-optical \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (i.e. an arbitrary non-symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary that Pytheus will optimize).  \n \u2022 Its three outputs go to number-resolving detectors H0,H1,H2. We post-select on **exactly two** clicks.  \n\n3) Heralding\u2192routing  \n \u2022 Click pattern {H0,H1} implements a Bell-measurement on (A,B) \u2192 **teleport** A\u2192B\u2032.  \n \u2022 Click pattern {H1,H2} implements a Bell-measurement on (A,C) \u2192 **teleport** A\u2192C\u2032.  \n \u2022 Other patterns are discarded.  \n\n4) Outcome  \n \u2022 Depending on which two detectors click, the unknown state at A lands at **either** B\u2032 **or** C\u2032 (up to known Pauli). You have built a **static teleportation\u2010router** whose routing decision is purely encoded in the non-reciprocal beam-splitting matrix and herald outcome\u2014no feed-forward required.  \n\n\u2014  \nWHY THIS IS NOVEL  \n \u2022 **Transformation primitive, not mere state generation**: it performs **conditional teleportation** to different recipients in a single device.  \n \u2022 **Hybridized mode**: mixes three modes (A,B,C) + vacuum implicitly in one 3\u00d73 interferometer.  \n \u2022 **Chiral light**: the 3\u00d73 unitary need **not** be symmetric; the non-reciprocity is key to making the two Bell-measurements orthogonal and linked to distinct herald patterns.  \n \u2022 I\u2019m unaware of any purely static linear-optical network that routes teleportation to different nodes via herald clicks.  \n\n\u2014  \nWHY PYTHEUS CAN DO IT  \n \u2022 Inputs: one single-photon emitter (A), two SPDC sources \u2192 total of five input modes (A,B,C,B\u2032,C\u2032).  \n \u2022 Linear optics only: a single 3\u00d73 coupler on (A,B,C) (the other modes B\u2032,C\u2032 bypass the network).  \n \u2022 Heralding: three number-resolving detectors; post-select on two clicks.  \n \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities or non-linear crystals beyond the SPDC sources.  \n\n\u2014  \nSKELETON Pytheus CONFIG  \n\n{  \n  \"description\":     \"Chiral teleportation switch: route A\u2192B\u2032 or A\u2192C\u2032 via one static 3\u00d73 coupler\",  \n  \"foldername\":      \"chiral_teleport_switch\",  \n  \"edges_tried\":     40,  \n  \"ftol\":            1e-06,  \n  \"loss_func\":       \"cr\",  \n  \"num_anc\":         0,                   # no extra ancillas beyond SPDC pairs  \n  \"num_pre\":         1,  \n  \"optimizer\":       \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  \"samples\":         10,  \n  \"target_quantum\":  [],                  # teleportation transformation via heralds  \n  \"in_nodes\":        [],                  # SPDC + emitter inject directly into network  \n  \"out_nodes\":       [3,4],               # modes B\u2032(3), C\u2032(4) receive teleported state  \n  \"anc_detectors\":   [5,6,7],             # H0\u2013H2 on outputs of the 3\u00d73 coupler  \n  \"heralding_out\":   [[5,6],[6,7]],       # {H0,H1}\u2192route to B\u2032; {H1,H2}\u2192route to C\u2032  \n  \"thresholds\":      [0.2,0.1],  \n  \"number_resolving\": true  \n}  \n\n\u2014  \nNEXT STEPS FOR THE EXPERT  \n1) Ask Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 subnetwork so that {H0,H1} and {H1,H2} enact two orthogonal Bell projectors on (A,B) and (A,C).  \n2) Check that the teleported fidelity to B\u2032 or C\u2032 exceeds classical bounds (>2/3).  \n3) Generalize to N-way teleportation routing by using an (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) chiral coupler + N-click herald patterns.  \n\nThis achieves a **novel, heralded \u201cteleportation switch\u201d** that fuses hybridized\u2010mode mixing with chiral non-reciprocal optics\u2014an ideal seed for a Phys. Rev. Lett. theory + Pytheus\u2010powered experiment."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"hybridized mode\" and \"chiral light\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals. A third input is vacuum (mode V).  We send modes B,C,V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical network with no symmetry constraint).  Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair.  By proper design of the 3\u00d73 unitary, these three detection patterns yield three orthogonal Bell-measurements, routing the entanglement along one of three distinct edges in the four-node network.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510        out node ]  \n             B\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524\u2500\u2510      \u250c\u2500 H0  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u2514\u2500[3\u00d73 coupler]\u2500 H1  \n             D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524               \u2514\u2500 H2  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n  After heralding on any two clicks among H0\u2013H2, the corresponding two remote modes are left in |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2022 Network transformation: a single multi\u2010outcome entanglement-swapping device.  \n  \u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u00d73 mixing of two photon modes + vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (no reciprocity assumption\u2014Pytheus can optimize arbitrary non-symmetric scattering matrix).  \n  \u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Opens a whole family of multi-way entanglement routers by changing the interferometer size and number of heralding ports.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: herald to entangle AD, AC or BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Bell correlations\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],            # Inputs: SPDC sources and vacuum connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],     # modes A(0),D(3),C(1),B(2) for various herald patterns\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],       # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,6]],  \n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n\u2013 Run Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler so that the three herald patterns project onto the three different Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 Verify orthogonality of heralded projectors.  \n\u2013 Generalize to an N-way entanglement router by using an (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) chiral hybrid coupler and selecting N-click patterns.\n\nThis achieves a novel multi-outcome entanglement\u2010swapping primitive in a single static linear-optical device.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This 3-way chiral router closely parallels existing multi-outcome entanglement routers in the ensemble. To achieve novelty, you need a fundamentally new primitive\u2014such as a non-commuting sequence of multi-party swaps, higher-order causal superpositions, or a genuinely new topological routing function\u2014rather than simply another herald-pattern conditional swap.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three ways to marry \u201chybridized mode\u201d and \u201cchiral light\u201d in a purely linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded quantum\u2010network task (no state\u2010generation target):  \n  a) A 2\u00d72 directional (chiral) coupler that swaps entanglement with tunable Schmidt weights (too close to PT\u2010swap proposals).  \n  b) A 3\u2010port chiral tritter that routes one Bell pair into two possible entanglement links (pushed complexity, similar ideas exist).  \n  c) A 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d which, by heralding two\u2010click patterns among its three outputs, implements three orthogonal Bell\u2010measurements in one device\u2014thereby routing entanglement along one of three distinct edges in a four\u2010node network.  \nStep 2: I checked novelty and feasibility:  \n  \u2013 (c) is novel\u2014nobody has proposed a single static interferometer that, depending on which two detectors click, conditionally realizes three different Bell\u2010swap channels (A\u2013D, A\u2013C, or B\u2013D).  \n  \u2013 It is feasible for Pytheus because it uses only two SPDC sources (Bell pairs), one vacuum port, a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (no symmetry constraints), and three photon\u2010number\u2010resolving heralding detectors. No dynamic feedback, no cavities.  \nStep 3: I pick (c) as the final idea.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201c3-Way Chiral Entanglement Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: two independent SPDC sources create Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). A third input is vacuum (mode V).  \n  \u2022 Coupler: B,C,V are injected into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear-optical interferometer with no reciprocity constraint.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs are monitored by photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0, H1, H2. We post-select on exactly two clicks. There are three possible two\u2010click patterns, each implementing a different Bell projection on which two of {B,C,V} were measured:  \n     1) {H0,H1} heralds a Bell\u2010measurement on B&C \u2192 entangles A\u2013D  \n     2) {H0,H2} heralds B&V \u2192 entangles A\u2013C  \n     3) {H1,H2} heralds C&V \u2192 entangles B\u2013D  \n  \u2022 Outputs: the un-measured two modes are left in a Bell state. By which pair clicks, the router \u201cchooses\u201d which link in the four-node network carries the entanglement, all in one static device.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum-network primitive: a multi-outcome entanglement-swapping router.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing B,C,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding; no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable to N-way routers by expanding to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: conditional Bell swaps AD/AC/BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],      # Bell correlations\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # SPDC sources inject directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],        # A(0), D(3), C(1), B(2) depending on herald\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],          # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,6]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n\u2013 Run Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler\u2019s internal beam splitters and phases so that each two\u2010click pattern implements one of the three orthogonal Bell projections.  \n\u2013 Verify that the resulting heralds indeed route entanglement along the intended edge.  \n\u2013 Extend to N-way routing by increasing the interferometer dimension and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal is too close to existing multi-way entanglement routers. No feedback or cavities.\nStep 3: Chose (c).\nStep 4: Novelty: Embeds both \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u2010mode mixing: the two idler modes plus vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (a fully non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary) into a single Bell\u2010analyzer, enabling unambiguous discrimination of three qutrit\u2010Bell states.  \nStep 5: Feasibility: Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics + heralding paradigm.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Qutrit Bell\u2010State Analyzer\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: two independent qutrit\u2010SPDC sources create Bell\u2010pairs on modes (A0,A1,A2) & (B0,B1,B2). We feed the idler modes A1,B1 and a vacuum ancilla V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no symmetry constraint on its unitary).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0,H1,H2. We post\u2010select on exactly two detectors clicking.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: engineer the 3\u00d73 unitary so that these three distinct two\u2010click patterns project onto three orthogonal qutrit\u2010Bell states:\n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H1} \u2194 \u03a8\u2080 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2081 = |01\u27e9+|12\u27e9+|20\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H1,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2082 = |02\u27e9+|10\u27e9+|21\u27e9  \n    Any other click pattern is a \u201cfailure.\u201d  \n  \u2022 This device thus unambiguously discriminates three qutrit\u2010Bell states with success probability >1/3, exploiting nonreciprocal mixing to break the usual SU(3) symmetry.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Foundational network primitive: high\u2010dimensional Bell measurement for qutrit teleportation and entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing A1,B1,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding; no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens the door to chiral analyzers in higher dimensions and multi\u2010outcome network coding.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral qutrit Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_qutrit_bell\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          1,            # vacuum ancilla\n  \"num_pre\":          2,            # two SPDC qutrit sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"0011\",\"1122\",\"2200\"],  # abstract labels for \u03a8\u2080,\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],           # sources connect directly to the network\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [6,7,8],      # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[6,7],[6,8],[7,8]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n\u2013 Run Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler\u2019s beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases so that the three two\u2010click patterns correspond to the desired qutrit\u2010Bell projectors.  \n\u2013 Verify discrimination fidelity and success probability.  \n\u2013 Generalize to four\u2010outcome or higher\u2010dimensional analyzers by expanding the interferometer dimension and ancilla count."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. By sweeping each R\u1d62 from \u00bd (weak, unsharp) to 1 (ultrastrong, near-projective) coupling, we realize a genuine measurement-induced quantum network primitive and systematically explore how KCBS inequality violations survive under partial-strength sequential measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static LOQC Realization of the Entanglement-Assisted (2,3) Quantum Secret Sharing Supermap\n\nAbstract: We experimentally implement the EA(2,3) threshold secret-sharing supermap (target: EA_23_secret_share) as an entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting code using only passive linear optics, one single-photon emitter, and two pre-shared Bell-pair sources. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Testing Non-Commutativity of Dissipative Lindblad Channels via Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static, purely linear-optical network using two SPDC Bell-pair sources, amplitude- and phase-damping beam-splitter ancillas, and a post-selected Bell-state measurement to swap entanglement through the two Lindblad maps L\u2081 (amplitude damping) and L\u2082 (phase damping) in both orders. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While using a nonreciprocal \u201cchiral coupler\u201d to dial the entanglement degree in an entanglement\u2010swapping node is an appealing twist, it is essentially equivalent to the previously proposed PT-symmetric (non-Hermitian) Bell-state analyser or directional entanglement-swapping schemes. Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Swapping along one diagonal versus the other conditioned on different herald clicks is exactly the same high-level network task of \u201cselectable\u201d Bell projections, only dressed here with a nonreciprocal coupler rather than a multiport mesh. Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair. To clear the novelty bar, you must go beyond conditional routing with an extra vacuum port and herald patterns\u2014perhaps by embedding non-commuting causal orders, higher-order topological invariants, or truly new multipartite network functions that have not been explored.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Bell\u2010State Analyzer\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: an unknown two\u2010photon Bell state in modes A1,A2 and B1,B2, plus one ancilla SPDC pair on modes C1,C2.  \n  \u2022 Hybridization: feed A1,B1,C1 and vacuum V into a 4\u00d74 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no reciprocity constraint).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the four outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0\u2013H3. We post\u2010select on exactly two\u2010click events.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: three distinct detector pairs correspond uniquely to three Bell states of the original A\u2013B pair; any other pattern is \u201cfail.\u201d  \n  \u2022 Result: the analyzer unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states with success probability >\u00bd, thanks to the directionality of the coupler breaking the usual linear\u2010optics symmetry.\n\nVisualization (modes \u2192 coupler \u2192 detectors):\n  A1\u2500\u2510  \n       \u251c\u2500\u25ba  \n  B1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba 4\u00d74 chiral coupler \u2500\u25ba H0  \n  C1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba                 \u2500\u25ba H1  \n  V \u2500\u2518                  \u2500\u25ba H2  \n                         \u2500\u25ba H3  \n  A2,B2,C2 are idle outputs or dumped.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network functionality: a Bell\u2010measurement building block for teleportation/entanglement\u2010swapping networks.  \n  \u2013 Combines hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing and chiral (nonreciprocal) interferometry.  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of chiral analyzers by varying ancilla count and coupler size.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome Bell discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_bell_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\", \n  \"num_anc\":          2,            # one SPDC ancilla pair  \n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [],           # use heralding patterns instead of state vectors  \n  \"in_nodes\":         [],           # SPDC sources and vacuum connect to coupler  \n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7],     # H0\u2013H3  \n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,7]],  \n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n  1. Verify discrimination success rates exceed 50 %.  \n  3. Generalize to analyzers for higher\u2010dimensional entangled\u2010state sets or multiport chiral detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cChiral Bell\u2010State Analyzer\u201d is essentially another variant of the many recent linear\u2010optics Bell analyzers that break the 50% bound via non-reciprocal or non-Hermitian couplers (e.g. the PT\u2010symmetric/anti-PT analyzers, the topological bound-state designs, and the programmable ancilla-controlled coherent analyzers already in the ensemble). We post\u2010select on exactly two detectors clicking.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: engineer the 3\u00d73 unitary so that these three distinct two\u2010click patterns project onto three orthogonal qutrit\u2010Bell states:\n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H1} \u2194 \u03a8\u2080 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2081 = |01\u27e9+|12\u27e9+|20\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H1,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2082 = |02\u27e9+|10\u27e9+|21\u27e9  \n    Any other click pattern is a \u201cfailure.\u201d  \n  \u2022 This device thus unambiguously discriminates three qutrit\u2010Bell states with success probability >1/3, exploiting nonreciprocal mixing to break the usual SU(3) symmetry.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Foundational network primitive: high\u2010dimensional Bell measurement for qutrit teleportation and entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing A1,B1,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding;     "output": "Thought: The chiral qutrit\u2010Bell analyzer is merely the same asymmetric, nonreciprocal \u201cchiral coupler + ancilla heralding\u201d trick previously applied to qubits\u2014now lifted to d=3. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals. A third input is vacuum (mode V).  We send modes B,C,V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical network with no symmetry constraint).  Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair.  By proper design of the 3\u00d73 unitary, these three detection patterns yield three orthogonal Bell-measurements, routing the entanglement along one of three distinct edges in the four-node network.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510        out node ]  \n             B\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524\u2500\u2510      \u250c\u2500 H0  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u2514\u2500[3\u00d73 coupler]\u2500 H1  \n             D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524               \u2514\u2500 H2  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n  After heralding on any two clicks among H0\u2013H2, the corresponding two remote modes are left in |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2022 Network transformation: a single multi\u2010outcome entanglement-swapping device.  \n  \u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u00d73 mixing of two photon modes + vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (no reciprocity assumption\u2014Pytheus can optimize arbitrary non-symmetric scattering matrix).  \n  \u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Opens a whole family of multi-way entanglement routers by changing the interferometer size and number of heralding ports.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: herald to entangle AD, AC or BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # light\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network task (no state\u2010generation):\n  a) Tunable nonreciprocal 2\u00d72 swap coupler (too close to PT\u2010swap).\n  b) Three\u2010port chiral tritter for two\u2010way routing (similar to existing routers).\n  c) A chiral linear\u2010optical Bell\u2010state analyzer: use a non-symmetric (\u201cchiral\u201d) interferometer to mix an unknown two-photon Bell state with ancilla photons in hybridized spatial modes, so that distinct two-click patterns unambiguously identify three out of the four Bell states.  \nStep 2: Novelty & discrimination beyond 50%.  \n  \u2022 Feasibility: It uses only SPDC sources, static linear optics (a chiral hybrid coupler), vacuum ancillas, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving heralds\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (no feedback, no cavities).  \nStep 3: Pick (c) as final idea.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it embeds \u201chybridized mode\u201d processing (mixing four spatial modes) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (a non\u2010symmetric 4\u00d74 linear network) into a Bell\u2010state analyzer, achieving three\u2010state discrimination in one static device\u2014no previous proposal uses directionality to break the Bell\u2010state symmetry in this way.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it only demands probabilistic pair\u2010sources, a multiport interferometer to be optimized, and heralding detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Bell\u2010State Analyzer\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: an unknown two\u2010photon Bell state in modes A1,A2 and B1,B2, plus one ancilla SPDC pair on modes C1,C2.  \n  \u2022 Hybridization: feed A1,B1,C1 and vacuum V into a 4\u00d74 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no reciprocity constraint).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the four outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0\u2013H3. We post\u2010select on exactly two\u2010click events.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: three distinct detector pairs correspond uniquely to three Bell states of the original A\u2013B pair; any other pattern is \u201cfail.\u201d  \n  \u2022 Result: the analyzer unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states with success probability >\u00bd, thanks to the directionality of the coupler breaking the usual linear\u2010optics symmetry.\n\nVisualization (modes \u2192 coupler \u2192 detectors):\n  A1\u2500\u2510  \n       \u251c\u2500\u25ba  \n  B1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba 4\u00d74 chiral coupler \u2500\u25ba H0  \n  C1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba                 \u2500\u25ba H1  \n  V \u2500\u2518                  \u2500\u25ba H2  \n                         \u2500\u25ba H3  \n  A2,B2,C2 are idle outputs or dumped.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network functionality: a Bell\u2010measurement building block for teleportation/entanglement\u2010swapping networks.  \n  \u2013 Combines hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing and chiral (nonreciprocal) interferometry.  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of chiral analyzers by varying ancilla count and coupler size.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome Bell discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_bell_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\", \n  \"num_anc\":          2,            # We feed the idler modes A1,B1 and a vacuum ancilla V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no symmetry constraint on its unitary).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0,H1,H2. We post\u2010select on exactly two detectors clicking.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: engineer the 3\u00d73 unitary so that these three distinct two\u2010click patterns project onto three orthogonal qutrit\u2010Bell states:\n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H1} \u2194 \u03a8\u2080 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2081 = |01\u27e9+|12\u27e9+|20\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H1,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2082 = |02\u27e9+|10\u27e9+|21\u27e9  \n    Any other click pattern is a \u201cfailure.\u201d  \n  \u2022 This device thus unambiguously discriminates three qutrit\u2010Bell states with success probability >1/3, exploiting nonreciprocal mixing to break the usual SU(3) symmetry.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Foundational network primitive: high\u2010dimensional Bell measurement for qutrit teleportation and entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing A1,B1,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding;     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to marry \u201chybridized mode\u201d and \u201cchiral light\u201d in a purely linear\u2010optical network task (no state\u2010generation):  \n  a) A directional 2\u00d72 coupler that swaps entanglement with tunable weights (too close to PT\u2010swap).  \n  b) A 3\u2010port chiral router heralding two possible swap paths (resembles existing routers).  \n  c) A 4\u2010mode \u201cchiral teleportation router\u201d that takes two unknown qubits plus two ancilla halves of Bell pairs, mixes them in a non\u2010symmetric 4\u00d74 interferometer, and\u2014by postselecting on two specific detector clicks\u2014both teleports the two qubits and routes them either as identity or swapped outputs.  \nStep 2: Evaluate novelty & feasibility:  \n  \u2022 Novelty: I\u2019ve never seen a single static linear\u2010optical device that simultaneously teleports two unknown photonic qubits and, via which pair of herald detectors click, reconfigures whether they arrive in the same order or swapped order at two remote nodes. This embeds \u201chybridized mode\u201d mixing (4\u2010mode coupler) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (non\u2010symmetric unitary) into teleportation routing.  \n  \u2022 Feasibility in Pytheus: uses two SPDC pair sources, two unknown\u2010photon inputs, one static 4\u00d74 interferometer (no symmetry constraints), two heralding detectors, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s linear\u2010optics + heralding framework.  \nStep 3: Pick (c).  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it fuses teleportation and routing in one static \u201cchiral\u201d measurement device\u2014achieving two\u2010qubit teleportation plus conditional swap purely by which detectors click.  \nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only requires probabilistic SPDC sources, a 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network to be optimized, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving heralds; pytheus can optimize the beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases of the chiral interferometer to realize the two orthogonal Bell\u2010measurement projectors that yield the identity vs. swap teleportation channels.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Teleportation Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs:\n    \u2013 Two unknown single\u2010photon qubits in abstract modes Q0 and Q1.  \n    \u2013 Two SPDC pair sources producing Bell halves on modes A0\u2013B0 and A1\u2013B1.  \n    \u2013 We inject Q0,A0,Q1,A1 into a single 4\u00d74 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical unitary with no reciprocity constraint).  \n  \u2022 Heralding:\n    \u2013 The four outputs of the coupler are labelled H0,H1,T0,T1.  \n    \u2013 H0 and H1 go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors; T0 and T1 are the teleported\u2010output ports delivered to two remote parties (Bob0 and Bob1).  \n    \u2013 We post\u2010select on exactly two clicks in {H0,H1,H2,H3}, but focus on two distinct two\u2010click patterns:\n       1) {H0,H1} heralds the \u201cidentity teleportation\u201d Bell measurement: Q0\u2192T0, Q1\u2192T1.  \n       2) {H0,H2} (or another fixed pair) heralds the \u201cswap teleportation\u201d Bell measurement: Q0\u2192T1, Q1\u2192T0.  \n  \u2022 Network transformation:\n    \u2013 In one static device, and with only which\u2010detector clicks, we both teleport the two unknown qubits across the pre\u2010shared Bell links and decide whether they arrive in the same order or swapped order at the receivers\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward needed.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top \u2192 bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ Q0 ]\u2500\u2500\u2510             \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2510          \n  SPDC: [ A0 ]\u2500\u2500\u2524 \u2502          \n                   \u2514\u2500[4\u00d74 chiral coupler]\u2500\u2500 H0 (det)  \n  SPDC: [ Q1 ]\u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u2500\u2500 H1 (det)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2510                 \u2500\u2500 T0 (out to Bob0)  \n  SPDC: [ A1 ]\u2500\u2500\u2524 \u2502                 \u2500\u2500 T1 (out to Bob1)  \n                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500  \n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum\u2010network primitive: simultaneous two\u2010qubit teleportation + conditional routing in one static device.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (4\u2010mode mixing of Q0,A0,Q1,A1) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 4\u00d74 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + heralding; no feedback, no cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to N\u2010qubit teleportation routers by scaling to (2N)\u00d7(2N) couplers and varied herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral teleportation router: 2-qubit teleport + identity vs swap by herald clicks\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_teleport_router_2q\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          2,                  # two SPDC sources  \n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],                 # Q0,A0,Q1,A1 injected directly  \n  \"out_nodes\":        [2,3],              # T0,T1 (the teleported outputs)  \n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5],              # H0,H1  \n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6]],      # two patterns: identity vs swap  \n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n  1.
