We feed the idler modes A1,B1 and a vacuum ancilla V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no symmetry constraint on its unitary).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0,H1,H2. We post\u2010select on exactly two detectors clicking.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: engineer the 3\u00d73 unitary so that these three distinct two\u2010click patterns project onto three orthogonal qutrit\u2010Bell states:\n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H1} \u2194 \u03a8\u2080 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2081 = |01\u27e9+|12\u27e9+|20\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H1,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2082 = |02\u27e9+|10\u27e9+|21\u27e9  \n    Any other click pattern is a \u201cfailure.\u201d  \n  \u2022 This device thus unambiguously discriminates three qutrit\u2010Bell states with success probability >1/3, exploiting nonreciprocal mixing to break the usual SU(3) symmetry.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Foundational network primitive: high\u2010dimensional Bell measurement for qutrit teleportation and entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing A1,B1,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding; A third input mode is vacuum (V).  \n  \u2022 Modes B, C, V are injected into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear-optical network without reciprocity constraints.  \n  \u2022 The three outputs are monitored by photon-number-resolving detectors H0, H1, H2. We post-select on exactly two clicks. There are three distinct two-click patterns:  \n      \u2013 {H0,H1} \u2192 projects B & C, leaving A & D entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H0,H2} \u2192 projects B & V, leaving A & C entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H1,H2} \u2192 projects C & V, leaving B & D entangled.  \n  \u2022 In each heralded case the unmeasured two modes collapse into a Bell pair. By which detectors click, the network \u201croutes\u201d entanglement along one of three edges in the four-node graph.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum-network primitive: a single static device implementing a three-outcome entanglement-swapping router.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non-symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC, vacuum ancilla, and heralding; no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to N-way routers by expanding to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: conditional Bell swaps AD/AC/BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          2,                # two SPDC sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # SPDC sources + vacuum connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],        # A(0), D(3), C(1), B(2) for different heralds\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],          # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,6]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n  1. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201chybridized mode\u201d and \u201cchiral light\u201d into a bona fide quantum\u2010network primitive (no state\u2010generation target):\n  a) A directional 2\u00d72 coupler that swaps with tunable Schmidt weights (too close to PT\u2010swap).  \n  b) A 3\u2010way entanglement router via a 3\u00d73 chiral coupler (resembles earlier multi\u2010outcome routers).  \n  c) A single\u2010stage \u201cchiral purification\u2010swap\u201d node: feed two raw Bell pairs plus a vacuum mode into a nonreciprocal hybrid coupler; heralding both purifies and swaps entanglement in one passive device.  \nStep 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 Novelty: I know of no linear\u2010optical proposal that merges purification and entanglement swapping into one static, directionally biased interferometer. It uses hybridized mixing of three modes (two idlers + vacuum) and chiral (asymmetric) beam\u2010splitter ratios to optimally trade off purification success and overall fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Feasibility in Pytheus: relies solely on two probabilistic SPDC sources, one vacuum input, a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (no symmetry constraint), and three photon\u2010number\u2010resolving heralds. No dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s domain.  \nStep 3: Pick (c).\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it embeds an entanglement\u2010purification protocol and an entanglement\u2010swapping operation into a single nonreciprocal multiport device, exploiting \u201chybridized mode\u201d mixing and \u201cchiral light\u201d to outperform any symmetric two\u2010stage scheme.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it only needs SPDC pair sources, vacuum ancilla, static linear optics, and heralding detectors\u2014and Pytheus can optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler\u2019s beam\u2010splitters and phases to maximize the purified Bell\u2010fidelity after one heralded click pattern.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Purification\u2013Swap Node\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: two independent SPDC sources create noisy Bell pairs on modes (A,B) and (C,D). A third input is vacuum (mode V).  \n  \u2022 Coupler: modes B,C,V are injected into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear\u2010optical interferometer with no reciprocity constraint.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0, H1, H2. We post\u2010select on exactly two clicks in a single fixed pattern (say {H0,H1}).  \n  \u2022 Transformation: conditioned on that two\u2010click herald, the remaining modes A & D emerge in a Bell state whose fidelity F_purified exceeds what you\u2019d achieve by (i) first performing a symmetric purification step on (A,B)+(C,D) and then (ii) swapping in a second device. Tuning the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry (via the internal beam\u2010splitter ratios) smoothly trades off raw success probability vs. final fidelity, and Pytheus finds the optimal mix.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2510                    out A ]  \n               B\u2500\u2500\u2510           \u250c\u2500 H0 (det)  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u251c\u2500\u25ba 3\u00d73 coupler \u2500 H1 (det)  \n               D\u2500\u2500\u2518           \u2514\u2500 H2 (det)  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                    out D ]\n\nAfter herald clicks {H0,H1}, modes A & D are left in the purified\u2010and\u2010swapped Bell state.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network transformation: combines entanglement\u2010purification and entanglement\u2010swapping into one static device.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non-symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical: two SPDC sources, vacuum ancilla, static 3\u00d73 interferometer, and heralding detectors; no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable: chain many such chiral purification\u2010swap nodes in a repeater architecture to optimize resource overhead and fidelity trade-offs.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral purification\u2010swap node: one\u2010step purify+swap via directional 3\u00d73 coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_purif_swap\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          2,                # two SPDC pair sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          15,\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # A,B,C,D,V connect directly\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [5,6,7],          # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[5,6]],          # fixed two\u2010click pattern for purify+swap\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n  1. Benchmark against the two-stage symmetric purification+swapping protocol to quantify the directional advantage.  \n  3. This blends \u201chybridized mode\u201d mixing (multiple spatial/polarization modes in one interferometer) with \u201cchiral light\u201d (a non\u2010symmetric unitary) to achieve indefinite causal order of two entanglement\u2010swapping channels without any active feed\u2010forward, purely via heralding. It\u2019s novel (no prior Bell\u2010swap switch in superposition of orders) and fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: SPDC sources, a single static multiport, vacuum inputs, and photon\u2010counting heralds.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Resources:\n    \u2013 Two independent SPDC sources produce Bell pairs on modes (A\u2013B) and (C\u2013D).  \n    \u2013 One single photon control qubit on mode E, prepared in the superposition |H\u27e9+|V\u27e9 (encoded abstractly).  \n    \u2013 One vacuum ancillary mode V.  \n  \u2022 Static network:\n    \u2013 All five modes B, C, E, V plus one vacuum port pass through a single static 5\u00d75 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear\u2010optical network without reciprocity constraints, mixing spatial and polarization paths.  \n    \u2013 The design routes the two idler photons B, C through two 2\u00d72 sub\u2010couplers (Swap\u2010station 1 and Swap\u2010station 2) in opposite orders depending on the control\u2019s polarization path, but all realized in one chiral 5\u00d75 unitary.  \n  \u2022 Heralding:\n    \u2013 Two of the five outputs (ancilla slots) are monitored by photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0 and H1. We post\u2010select on one\u2010click in each detector (two\u2010click event).  \n  \u2022 Operation:\n    \u2013 Conditioned on H0+H1 clicks, the control qubit E remains coherently entangled with whether the swap network applied \u201cSwap1\u2192Swap2\u201d vs. \u201cSwap2\u2192Swap1\u201d to the two Bell\u2010pair idlers.  \n    \u2013 The two remote photons A and D emerge in a superposition of being entangled by the first\u2010then\u2010second swap vs. second\u2010then\u2010first swap\u2014i.e. a superposition of two distinct network orders.  \n    \u2013 No dynamic feed\u2010forward is needed: the entire causal\u2010order superposition is built into the static chiral coupler and heralding.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum\u2010network primitive well beyond state generation: a genuine \u201cquantum switch\u201d building block for entanglement distribution with indefinite causal order.  \n  \u2013 Combines hybridized\u2010mode mixing (spatial + polarization modes in one interferometer) and chiral light (non\u2010symmetric 5\u00d75 unitary) in a meaningful, new way.  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical: uses only SPDC sources, a vacuum port, a single static multiport coupler, and photon\u2010counting heralds. No active feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of higher\u2010order network supermaps and causal\u2010order experiments by generalizing to more swaps or control qubits.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral quantum\u2010switch for two entanglement\u2010swap stations\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ent_switch\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          2,                # two SPDC Bell\u2010pair sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # A,B,C,D,E,V injected directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,4],          # A(0), D(3), E(4) survive herald\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [5,6],            # H0,H1 for two\u2010click herald\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[5,6]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n1.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201chybridized mode\u201d (multi\u2010mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal coupler) in a network transformation (no state\u2010generation):\n  a) 2\u00d72 directional swap coupler for tunable entanglement weights (too close to PT\u2010swap).  \n  b) 3-way 4-mode router for four nodes (resembles earlier multi-outcome routers).  \n  c) Chiral entanglement\u2010rotator on a triangle: start with three Bell pairs on A_i\u2013B_i, i=1..3; mix the three idler photons B1,B2,B3 in a single non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer; three distinct two-click herald patterns conditionally rotate the entanglement pairing around the triangle (identity, +1 cycle, \u20131 cycle).  \nStep 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n  \u2022 Novel \u2013 no prior linear\u2010optical device rotates the entanglement\u2010graph of a three\u2010node cycle by chiral mixing and heralding.  \n  \u2022 Feasible \u2013 uses only three probabilistic SPDC sources, a static 3\u00d73 linear-optical network (no symmetry constraint), and three photon-number-resolving heralds; Pytheus can optimize beam splitters and phases for this.  \nStep 3: Pick (c).\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a one-shot entanglement-graph rotation in a triangular network via a single \u201cchiral\u201d hybrid coupler and heralding, generalizing entanglement swapping to cyclic graph transformations.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires SPDC pair sources, a 3\u00d73 interferometer to optimize, and heralding detectors; no feedback or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement Rotator\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: three independent SPDC sources create Bell pairs on modes (A\u2081\u2013B\u2081), (A\u2082\u2013B\u2082), (A\u2083\u2013B\u2083).  \n  \u2022 Coupler: the three idler photons B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 are injected into one static 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (an arbitrary non\u2010symmetric unitary mixing these modes).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: its three outputs go to photon\u2010number-resolving detectors H\u2080,H\u2081,H\u2082. We post-select on exactly two clicks; there are three two-click patterns which we label by which pair of detectors clicked:\n      \u2013 {H\u2080,H\u2081} \u2192 \u201cidentity\u201d swap: leaves pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2081, A\u2082\u2013B\u2082, A\u2083\u2013B\u2083  \n      \u2013 {H\u2081,H\u2082} \u2192 \u201cforward rotation\u201d: yields pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2082, A\u2082\u2013B\u2083, A\u2083\u2013B\u2081  \n      \u2013 {H\u2080,H\u2082} \u2192 \u201cbackward rotation\u201d: yields pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2083, A\u2082\u2013B\u2081, A\u2083\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Network transformation: by choosing which detectors click, the device \u201crotates\u201d the entanglement graph on the three\u2010node cycle in one static chiral coupler.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Fundamental network primitive: cyclic entanglement-graph reconfiguration.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC + heralding; no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable: N-node cyclic routers by scaling to N\u00d7N couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement rotator on a 3-node cycle\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_cycle_rotator\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          3,                # three SPDC sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"000\",\"111\"],    # abstract: correlated bits on each pair\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083,B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,2,4,1,3,5],     # A\u2081(0),B\u2081(1),A\u2082(2),B\u2082(3),A\u2083(4),B\u2083(5)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [6,7,8],          # H\u2080\u2013H\u2082\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[6,7],[7,8],[6,8]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n  1.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. By sweeping each R\u1d62 from \u00bd (weak, unsharp) to 1 (ultrastrong, near-projective) coupling, we realize a genuine measurement-induced quantum network primitive and systematically explore how KCBS inequality violations survive under partial-strength sequential measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static LOQC Realization of the Entanglement-Assisted (2,3) Quantum Secret Sharing Supermap\n\nAbstract: We experimentally implement the EA(2,3) threshold secret-sharing supermap (target: EA_23_secret_share) as an entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting code using only passive linear optics, one single-photon emitter, and two pre-shared Bell-pair sources.  By mixing the dealer\u2019s unknown qubit with the Bell halves into three optical share modes via beam splitters and phase shifters, any two players can cooperatively route their modes through a static LOQC decoder and heraldedly reconstruct the dealer\u2019s secret, while individual players gain no information.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum-Controlled Time-Bin Basis Entanglement Swapping in the Telecom Band\n\nAbstract: We realize a basis-controlled entanglement swapping protocol for telecom-band time-bin qubits by preparing a single-photon control qubit in the superposition (|early\u232a+e^{i\u03c6}|late\u232a) to route two SPDC-generated Bell pairs between nodes A\u2013R and R\u2013C into either a Z-basis (M_Z) or an X-basis (M_X) Bell-swap module. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Temporal-Mode Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping with Single Ancilla\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical station that uses one ancilla Bell pair and a single delay loop to perform two sequential entanglement swaps on unknown qubit pairs arriving in time bins t\u2081 and t\u2082, halving the ancillary resource requirement. The experiment explicitly targets eight two-click detection patterns (four at t\u2081, four at t\u2082) on number-resolving, time-tagging detectors, each pattern heralding a successful swap and showcasing a resonator-inspired temporal coupling strategy for resource-efficient quantum network primitives.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed chiral entanglement\u2010router is essentially another variant of the static entanglement-routing primitives already covered in the ensemble (for instance the \u201cMultiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d) and the directional swapping schemes (PT-symmetric or skin-effect couplers) for on-demand routing. A third input is vacuum (mode V).  We send modes B,C,V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical network with no symmetry constraint).  Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair.  By proper design of the 3\u00d73 unitary, these three detection patterns yield three orthogonal Bell-measurements, routing the entanglement along one of three distinct edges in the four-node network.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510        out node ]  \n             B\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524\u2500\u2510      \u250c\u2500 H0  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u2514\u2500[3\u00d73 coupler]\u2500 H1  \n             D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524               \u2514\u2500 H2  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n  After heralding on any two clicks among H0\u2013H2, the corresponding two remote modes are left in |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2022 Network transformation: a single multi\u2010outcome entanglement-swapping device.  \n  \u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u00d73 mixing of two photon modes + vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (no reciprocity assumption\u2014Pytheus can optimize arbitrary non-symmetric scattering matrix).  \n  \u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Opens a whole family of multi-way entanglement routers by changing the interferometer size and number of heralding ports.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: herald to entangle AD, AC or BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # We post\u2010select on exactly two detectors clicking.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: engineer the 3\u00d73 unitary so that these three distinct two\u2010click patterns project onto three orthogonal qutrit\u2010Bell states:\n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H1} \u2194 \u03a8\u2080 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9+|22\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H0,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2081 = |01\u27e9+|12\u27e9+|20\u27e9  \n      \u2013 Pattern {H1,H2} \u2194 \u03a8\u2082 = |02\u27e9+|10\u27e9+|21\u27e9  \n    Any other click pattern is a \u201cfailure.\u201d  \n  \u2022 This device thus unambiguously discriminates three qutrit\u2010Bell states with success probability >1/3, exploiting nonreciprocal mixing to break the usual SU(3) symmetry.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Foundational network primitive: high\u2010dimensional Bell measurement for qutrit teleportation and entanglement\u2010swapping protocols.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing A1,B1,V) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 3\u00d73 interferometer).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + vacuum + heralding; no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens the door to chiral analyzers in higher dimensions and multi\u2010outcome network coding.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral qutrit Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_qutrit_bell\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          1,            # vacuum ancilla\n  \"num_pre\":          2,            # two SPDC qutrit sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"0011\",\"1122\",\"2200\"],  # abstract labels for \u03a8\u2080,\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],           # sources connect directly to the network\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [6,7,8],      # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[6,7],[6,8],[7,8]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n\u2013 Run Pytheus to optimize the 3\u00d73 coupler\u2019s beam\u2010splitter ratios and phases so that the three two\u2010click patterns correspond to the desired qutrit\u2010Bell projectors.  \n\u2013 Verify discrimination fidelity and success probability.  \n\u2013 Generalize to four\u2010outcome or higher\u2010dimensional analyzers by expanding the interferometer dimension and ancilla count.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The chiral qutrit\u2010Bell analyzer is merely the same asymmetric, nonreciprocal \u201cchiral coupler + ancilla heralding\u201d trick previously applied to qubits\u2014now lifted to d=3. We post-select on exactly two clicks. There are three distinct two-click patterns:  \n      \u2013 {H0,H1} \u2192 projects B & C, leaving A & D entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H0,H2} \u2192 projects B & V, leaving A & C entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H1,H2} \u2192 projects C & V, leaving B & D entangled.  \n  \u2022 In each heralded case the unmeasured two modes collapse into a Bell pair. By which detectors click, the network \u201croutes\u201d entanglement along one of three edges in the four-node graph.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum-network primitive: a single static device implementing a three-outcome entanglement-swapping router.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non-symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC, vacuum ancilla, and heralding; no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to N-way routers by expanding to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: conditional Bell swaps AD/AC/BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          2,                # two SPDC sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # SPDC sources + vacuum connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3,1,2],        # A(0), D(3), C(1), B(2) for different heralds\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6],          # H0\u2013H2\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,6]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n  1. A third input is vacuum (mode V).  \n  \u2022 Coupler: modes B,C,V are injected into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d\u2014i.e. a linear\u2010optical interferometer with no reciprocity constraint.  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the three outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0, H1, H2. Tuning the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry (via the internal beam\u2010splitter ratios) smoothly trades off raw success probability vs. final fidelity, and Pytheus finds the optimal mix.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2510                    out A ]  \n               B\u2500\u2500\u2510           \u250c\u2500 H0 (det)  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u251c\u2500\u25ba 3\u00d73 coupler \u2500 H1 (det)  \n               D\u2500\u2500\u2518           \u2514\u2500 H2 (det)  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518                    out D ]\n\nAfter herald clicks {H0,H1}, modes A & D are left in the purified\u2010and\u2010swapped Bell state.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network transformation: combines entanglement\u2010purification and entanglement\u2010swapping into one static device.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (three\u2010mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non-symmetric 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical: two SPDC sources, vacuum ancilla, static 3\u00d73 interferometer, and heralding detectors; We post-select on exactly two clicks; there are three two-click patterns which we label by which pair of detectors clicked:\n      \u2013 {H\u2080,H\u2081} \u2192 \u201cidentity\u201d swap: leaves pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2081, A\u2082\u2013B\u2082, A\u2083\u2013B\u2083  \n      \u2013 {H\u2081,H\u2082} \u2192 \u201cforward rotation\u201d: yields pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2082, A\u2082\u2013B\u2083, A\u2083\u2013B\u2081  \n      \u2013 {H\u2080,H\u2082} \u2192 \u201cbackward rotation\u201d: yields pairings A\u2081\u2013B\u2083, A\u2082\u2013B\u2081, A\u2083\u2013B\u2082  \n  \u2022 Network transformation: by choosing which detectors click, the device \u201crotates\u201d the entanglement graph on the three\u2010node cycle in one static chiral coupler.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Fundamental network primitive: cyclic entanglement-graph reconfiguration.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3-mode mixing) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal 3\u00d73 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear-optical with SPDC + heralding; no dynamic feed-forward or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Generalizable: N-node cyclic routers by scaling to N\u00d7N couplers and N-click herald patterns.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement rotator on a 3-node cycle\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_cycle_rotator\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          3,                # three SPDC sources\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"000\",\"111\"],    # abstract: correlated bits on each pair\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],               # A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083,B\u2081,B\u2082,B\u2083 connect directly\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,2,4,1,3,5],     # A\u2081(0),B\u2081(1),A\u2082(2),B\u2082(3),A\u2083(4),B\u2083(5)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [6,7,8],          # H\u2080\u2013H\u2082\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[6,7],[7,8],[6,8]],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nNext steps for the Expert:\n  1. Verify that each heralding event indeed yields the correct pairing of A\u1d62\u2013B_j.  \n  3. Extend to larger cyclic or more complex graph transformations by scaling the coupler dimension and herald patterns.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cChiral Entanglement Rotator\u201d is just another instance of the multi-outcome entanglement-routing primitives you\u2019ve already proposed (and that appear in the ensemble), merely scaling to three Bell pairs and a 3\u00d73 coupler. It adds no fundamentally new network task or resource\u2014only another conditional swap of predefined pairs via different two-click patterns.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing multi-way entanglement routers. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively new primitive (for example non-commuting multi-swap sequences, higher-order causal-order effects, or genuinely new topological routing operations), not just another herald-pattern conditional swap in a larger coupler."

The output is a non\u2010maximally entangled two\u2010photon state whose Schmidt weights are tunable via the coupler\u2019s directional reflectivities.\n  b) Chiral multiparty router: pre\u2010share Bell pairs between Alice\u2013Bob and Alice\u2013Charlie, then mix one photon from each pair in a three\u2010port \u201chybrid\u201d interferometer with built\u2010in directionality (chiral tritter). A heralded detection entangles Bob & Charlie in a path\u2010dependent way, realizing a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010routing network.\n  c) Directional superposition swap: implement two independent entanglement\u2010swapping stations, but interconnect them via a chiral two\u2013mode hybridized waveguide so that the two swap stations interfere directionally. The result is a coherent superposition of which swap succeeded\u2014i.e. entangling four distant parties in a \u201cwhich\u2010path\u201d superposition.\nStep 2: Check novelty and pytheus\u2010feasibility\n  a) Novel: no one has used directional (nonreciprocal) couplers for entanglement swapping to tune the output entanglement. Feasible: uses only linear optics, ancillas, heralding. Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter transmissivities and source connections.\n  b) Interesting but more complex\u2014three\u2010port interferometer may push pytheus\u2019s mode count high.\n  c) Quite exotic\u2014superposition of two swap stations requires interference of ancillas across setups\u2014harder to converge.\nStep 3: Pick (a) as most promising.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because: \n  \u2013 No existing quantum\u2010optics candidate has exploited chiral (direction\u2010dependent) coupling to steer entanglement\u2010swapping weights. It blends nonreciprocal routing and hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing into a single measurement device, giving direct control over the entanglement spectrum.\nStep 5: This is feasible in pytheus because: \n  \u2013 It only uses two standard SPDC pair sources (probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources), a single directional/hybrid beam splitter (modeled by tunable transmissivities), two heralding detectors, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feedforward or cavities, fully within pytheus\u2019s optimization of linear\u2010optical networks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nHere is a concrete target for Pytheus\u2014the \u201cChiral Entanglement-Swapping Router\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two independent probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources producing Bell pairs (A\u2013B and C\u2013D). Photons B and C are sent into a single \u201cchiral coupler\u201d\u2014a two\u2010input, two\u2010output linear\u2010optical network whose reflectivity and transmissivity differ for the two propagation directions (this abstracts our chiral\u2010light element). This coupler acts as a \u201chybridized mode\u201d device, mixing the spatial modes of B and C in a directionally dependent fashion. Two detectors herald a joint measurement on B and C after the chiral coupler. Conditioned on the two\u2010click heralding event, the remaining photons A and D collapse into the two\u2010photon state\n\n\u2003\u2003\u03a8_AD = \u03b1\u2009|0_A\u20090_D\u27e9 + \u03b2\u2009|1_A\u20091_D\u27e9,\u2003|\u03b1|\u00b2+|\u03b2|\u00b2=1,\n\nwhere the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 is directly set by the chiral coupler\u2019s asymmetry. By tuning the directional transmissivities of that coupler, one can dial continuously through the full family of non\u2010maximally entangled qubit pairs, exploring fundamental trade-offs in entanglement distribution under nonreciprocal routing.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n\n   Sources:    [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ A\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500B\u2500\u2500\\                herald_1\n                              >\u2014[ chiral BS ]\u2014\u2022\u2014 herald_2\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500C\u2500\u2500/                herald_ cats\n               [ SPDC ]\u2500\u2500D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2022                 out_ D\n\n  \u2022 herald detectors measure modes from B,C after the chiral BS;\n  A and D are left in the target entangled qubit state.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  - Quantum network task: entanglement swapping with tunable, directional mixing  \n  - Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (the coupler mixes two spatial modes into hybrid outputs) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (nonreciprocal transmissivities)  \n  - Fully linear\u2010optical, probabilistic sources + heralding, no feedback or cavities  \n  - Generalizes to families of couplers and network topologies (multi-node chiral routers)  \n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement swapping: tunable non-max entangled qubit via directional coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_ES\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      30,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"imaginary\":        false,\n  \"safe_hist\":        true,\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"amplitudes\":       [\"alpha\",\"beta\"],\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"single_emitters\":  [],\n  \"removed_connections\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nThe Expert can now ask Pytheus to find the exact network of beam splitters and phase shifters that implements this chiral coupler and realizes the heralded mapping to \u03a8_AD with the desired \u03b1/\u03b2 ratio.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This target is too close to the PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping scheme (non-Hermitian Bell analyzer with tunable \u03b3) and to earlier directional skin-effect swapping proposals. To be novel, you need a qualitatively new element\u2014e.g. a coupling that intermixes more than two paths in a truly non-reciprocal topological way, or a multi-party chiral-order of swaps that leads to an entanglement pattern unseen in the literature\u2014rather than just a tunable asymmetric 2\u00d72 coupler.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Photons B and C are fed into a single 4-mode \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear-optical interferometer whose scattering matrix is non-reciprocal). The four output ports of this coupler are monitored by detectors H0\u2013H3. We group these detectors into two heralding patterns:\n \u2022 Hdir = {H0,H1}: a \u201cdirect\u201d Bell measurement that swaps entanglement onto modes A & D.\n \u2022 Hcross = {H2,H3}: a \u201ccrossed\u201d Bell measurement that nonlocally entangles A\u2194C and B\u2194D (i.e. it routes the entanglement along the alternate diagonal of the 2\u00d72 node grid).\n\nConditioned on clicks in Hdir, the remaining photons on A,D collapse into a two-qubit Bell state. Conditioned on clicks in Hcross, entanglement is swapped across the cross edges\u2014A with C and B with D. The chiral coupler\u2019s internal phases and beam-splitter ratios can be tuned (and optimized by Pytheus) so that the two heralding channels are mutually orthogonal and implement the two distinct Bell projective measurements.\n\nThis device thus realizes a programmable entanglement router: by selecting which pair of heralding detectors clicks, one chooses the topology of the resulting entanglement graph, all in a single static linear-optical network.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral entanglement router: conditional swap AD vs cross-swap AC&BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_router_2p\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          4,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],        # SPDC sources input directly into the network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,3],     # modes A (detector 0) and D (detector 3)\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7], # H0\u2013H3\n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5]],   # Hdir channel: heralds entanglement on A,D\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert notes:\n\u2013 One Pytheus run finds the network for the \u201cdirect\u201d swap (heralding [H0,H1]).  \n\u2013 A second run (or minor variant) uses heralding_out=[[6,7]] to realize the \u201ccross\u201d swap.  \n\u2013 Pytheus will optimize the internal beam-splitters and phases of the 4-mode coupler such that the two heralding patterns implement orthogonal Bell measurements.  \n\u2013 This setup can be generalized to larger node grids and higher-order chiral routers by increasing the mode count and heralding patterns.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This falls too close to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d and \u201cdirectional/skin-effect swapping\u201d proposals. A third input is vacuum (mode V).  We send modes B,C,V into a single 3\u00d73 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (a linear\u2010optical network with no symmetry constraint).  Its three outputs go to photon-counting detectors H0,H1,H2.  We post\u2010select on exactly two of these detectors clicking.  There are three possible heralding patterns:\n\n    \u2022 {H0,H1} \u2192 project B,C\u2192H0,H1 so that A&D become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H0,H2} \u2192 project B,V\u2192H0,H2 so that A&C become entangled  \n    \u2022 {H1,H2} \u2192 project C,V\u2192H1,H2 so that B&D become entangled  \n\n  In each case the remaining two modes collapse into a maximally entangled Bell pair.  By proper design of the 3\u00d73 unitary, these three detection patterns yield three orthogonal Bell-measurements, routing the entanglement along one of three distinct edges in the four-node network.\n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ A\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510        out node ]  \n             B\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524\u2500\u2510      \u250c\u2500 H0  \n  SPDC: [ C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510   \u2514\u2500[3\u00d73 coupler]\u2500 H1  \n             D\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2524               \u2514\u2500 H2  \n  Vacuum: [ V\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2518  \n\n  After heralding on any two clicks among H0\u2013H2, the corresponding two remote modes are left in |00>+|11>.\n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2022 Network transformation: a single multi\u2010outcome entanglement-swapping device.  \n  \u2022 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (3\u00d73 mixing of two photon modes + vacuum) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (no reciprocity assumption\u2014Pytheus can optimize arbitrary non-symmetric scattering matrix).  \n  \u2022 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Opens a whole family of multi-way entanglement routers by changing the interferometer size and number of heralding ports.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n\n{\n  \"description\":      \"3-Way chiral entanglement router: herald to entangle AD, AC or BD\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"3way_chiral_router\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          0,\n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          10,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"00\",\"11\"],   # Analyzer\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\n  \u2022 Inputs: an unknown two\u2010photon Bell state in modes A1,A2 and B1,B2, plus one ancilla SPDC pair on modes C1,C2.  \n  \u2022 Hybridization: feed A1,B1,C1 and vacuum V into a 4\u00d74 \u201cchiral hybrid coupler\u201d (no reciprocity constraint).  \n  \u2022 Heralding: the four outputs go to photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors H0\u2013H3. We post\u2010select on exactly two\u2010click events.  \n  \u2022 Outcome mapping: three distinct detector pairs correspond uniquely to three Bell states of the original A\u2013B pair; any other pattern is \u201cfail.\u201d  \n  \u2022 Result: the analyzer unambiguously discriminates three out of four Bell states with success probability >\u00bd, thanks to the directionality of the coupler breaking the usual linear\u2010optics symmetry.\n\nVisualization (modes \u2192 coupler \u2192 detectors):\n  A1\u2500\u2510  \n       \u251c\u2500\u25ba  \n  B1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba 4\u00d74 chiral coupler \u2500\u25ba H0  \n  C1\u2500\u253c\u2500\u25ba                 \u2500\u25ba H1  \n  V \u2500\u2518                  \u2500\u25ba H2  \n                         \u2500\u25ba H3  \n  A2,B2,C2 are idle outputs or dumped.\n\nWhy this is a strong Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Network functionality: a Bell\u2010measurement building block for teleportation/entanglement\u2010swapping networks.  \n  \u2013 Combines hybridized spatial\u2010mode mixing and chiral (nonreciprocal) interferometry.  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical, ancilla\u2010heralded, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Opens a family of chiral analyzers by varying ancilla count and coupler size.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Chiral Bell\u2010state analyzer: unambiguous 3\u2010outcome Bell discrimination\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_bell_analyzer\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      50,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\", \n  \"num_anc\":          2,            # one SPDC ancilla pair  \n  \"num_pre\":          1,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [],           # use heralding patterns instead of state vectors  \n  \"in_nodes\":         [],           # SPDC sources and vacuum connect to coupler  \n  \"anc_detectors\":    [4,5,6,7],     # H0\u2013H3  \n  \"heralding_out\":    [[4,5],[4,6],[5,7]],  \n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nExpert next steps:\n  1. Run Pytheus to optimize the 4\u00d74 interferometer so that the chosen two\u2010click patterns implement three orthogonal Bell projectors.  \n  2. Verify discrimination success rates exceed 50 %.  \n  3. Generalize to analyzers for higher\u2010dimensional entangled\u2010state sets or multiport chiral detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This design overlaps closely with existing PT/anti-PT and symmetry-protected Bell\u2010state analyzers. To clear PRL novelty, please propose a fundamentally new measurement primitive\u2014such as a genuinely multi-outcome higher-dimensional Bell projector, a non-commuting causal-order analyzer, or a topologically driven multi-photon fusion that cannot be reduced to an asymmetric 4\u00d74 coupler with ancillas.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! T0 and T1 are the teleported\u2010output ports delivered to two remote parties (Bob0 and Bob1).  \n    \u2013 We post\u2010select on exactly two clicks in {H0,H1,H2,H3}, but focus on two distinct two\u2010click patterns:\n       1) {H0,H1} heralds the \u201cidentity teleportation\u201d Bell measurement: Q0\u2192T0, Q1\u2192T1.  \n       2) {H0,H2} (or another fixed pair) heralds the \u201cswap teleportation\u201d Bell measurement: Q0\u2192T1, Q1\u2192T0.  \n  \u2022 Network transformation:\n    \u2013 In one static device, and with only which\u2010detector clicks, we both teleport the two unknown qubits across the pre\u2010shared Bell links and decide whether they arrive in the same order or swapped order at the receivers\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward needed.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top \u2192 bottom):\n\n  SPDC: [ Q0 ]\u2500\u2500\u2510             \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2510          \n  SPDC: [ A0 ]\u2500\u2500\u2524 \u2502          \n                   \u2514\u2500[4\u00d74 chiral coupler]\u2500\u2500 H0 (det)  \n  SPDC: [ Q1 ]\u2500\u2500\u2510                     \u2500\u2500 H1 (det)  \n                 \u251c\u2500\u2510                 \u2500\u2500 T0 (out to Bob0)  \n  SPDC: [ A1 ]\u2500\u2500\u2524 \u2502                 \u2500\u2500 T1 (out to Bob1)  \n                   \u2514\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500  \n\nWhy this is a good Pytheus target:\n  \u2013 Quantum\u2010network primitive: simultaneous two\u2010qubit teleportation + conditional routing in one static device.  \n  \u2013 Combines \u201chybridized mode\u201d (4\u2010mode mixing of Q0,A0,Q1,A1) and \u201cchiral light\u201d (arbitrary non\u2010symmetric 4\u00d74 unitary).  \n  \u2013 Fully linear\u2010optical with SPDC + heralding; Other outcomes are discarded.  \n  \u2022 Mapping: In the computational basis |c,t1,t2\u27e9\u2192|c,t1\u2032,t2\u2032\u27e9 where t\u20321,t\u20322 = (t1,t2) if c=0, and (t2,t1) if c=1.\n\nSuggested Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\":      \"Heralded chiral Fredkin gate (controlled\u2010SWAP) via nonreciprocal coupler\",\n  \"foldername\":       \"chiral_fredkin\",\n  \"edges_tried\":      40,\n  \"ftol\":             1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\":        \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\":          2,                   # ancilla SPDC pair\n  \"num_pre\":          0,\n  \"optimizer\":        \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":          20,\n  \"target_quantum\":   [\"000000\",\"001001\",\"010010\",\"011011\",\"100100\",\"101110\",\"110101\",\"111111\"],\n  \"in_nodes\":         [],                  # C(0), T1(1), T2(2), A1(3), A2(4) connect to network\n  \"out_nodes\":        [0,1,2],             # modes for C, T1\u2032, T2\u2032 after herald\n  \"anc_detectors\":    [5,6],               # H0,H1 \n  \"heralding_out\":    [[5,6]],             # two\u2010click pattern heralds success\n  \"thresholds\":       [0.2,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true\n}\n\nHow to proceed:\n1. We post-select on exactly two clicks. There are three distinct two-click patterns:  \n      \u2013 {H0,H1} \u2192 projects B & C, leaving A & D entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H0,H2} \u2192 projects B & V, leaving A & C entangled.  \n      \u2013 {H1,H2} \u2192 projects C & V, leaving B & D entangled.  \n  \u2022 In each heralded case the unmeasured two modes collapse into a Bell pair.
